descriptionSet.description: On this advertisement for Lipton's Tea, a white woman with blonde hair, can be seen standing in front of a table set with steaming cups of tea, a container of creamer, sugar and a saucer. On the second shelf of the table, platters of biscuits and shortbread can be seen. The blonde lady holds out her cup to a native tea picker who pours her tea from a tea pot, across the hedge. The tea picker has a basket tied to her back.

A Cup full of Goodness from Lipton's Tea Gardens in Ceylon

description-en: On this advertisement for Lipton's Tea, a white woman with blonde hair, can be seen standing in front of a table set with steaming cups of tea, a container of creamer, sugar and a saucer. On the second shelf of the table, platters of biscuits and shortbread can be seen. The blonde lady holds out her cup to a native tea picker who pours her tea from a tea pot, across the hedge. The tea picker has a basket tied to her back. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The most dramatic expansion of tea consumption—and the development of relatively standardized chai (produced by boiling tea leaves in a mixture of milk, water, and sugar, with optional spices such as cardamom, cinnamon, clove, ginger, or black pepper)—only occurred after 1947 and the ensuing transfer of majority ownership in tea estates (which, significantly, were exempted from the sweeping land-reform legislation of the Nehru-Congress era) and in tea wholesaling companies from British to Indian hands. This shift is exemplified in this image, which recapitulates the popular visual trope of "the journey of tea" from tea-garden to consumer. (Philip Lutgendorf)(gs)
